translated: Subhūti, he also knows as it truly is the mental activities of those immeasurable and innumerable beings.

analyzed: tāni api subhūte tathāgataḥ sattva asadbhāva tayā eva prajānāti
translated: Subhūti, the Tathāgata knows those mental activities of beings because of the non-existence of beings.

original: evaṃ khalu subhūte prajñāpāramitāmāgamya tathāgato'prameyāṇāmasaṃkhyeyānāṃ sattvānāmaprameyāṇyasaṃkhyeyāni cittacaritāni ca yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti
analyzed: evam khalu subhūte prajñāpāramitām āgamya tathāgata uprameyāṇām asaṃkhyeyānām sattvānām aprameyāṇi asaṃkhyeyāni citta caritāni ca yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: In this way, Subhūti, the Tathāgata, by means of the perfection of wisdom, knows as it truly is the immeasurable and innumerable mental activities of immeasurable and innumerable beings.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte prajñāpāramitā tathāgatānāmarhatāṃ samyaksaṃbuddhānāmasya lokasya saṃdarśayitrī //
analyzed: evam hi subhūte prajñāpāramitā tathāgatānām arhatām samyaksaṃbuddhānām asya lokasya saṃdarśayitrī
translated: In this way, Subhūti, the perfection of wisdom reveals to the Tathāgatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Awakened Ones, this world.

original: punaraparaṃ subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāmasaṃkhyeyānāṃ sattvānāṃ saṃkṣiptāni cittāni saṃkṣiptāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: punar aparam subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām asaṃkhyeyānām sattvānām saṃkṣiptāni cittāni saṃkṣiptāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: Furthermore, Subhuti, the Tathagata, by means of this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is the contracted minds of immeasurable, incalculable beings as contracted minds.

original: kathaṃ ca subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāmasaṃkhyeyānāṃ sattvānāṃ saṃkṣiptāni cittāni saṃkṣiptāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: katham ca subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām asaṃkhyeyānām sattvānām saṃkṣiptāni cittāni saṃkṣiptāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam
translated: And how, Subhuti, does the Tathagata, by means of this perfection of wisdom, know as it really is the contracted minds of immeasurable, incalculable beings as contracted minds?

original: sa saṃkṣepaṃ kṣayataḥ kṣayaṃ ca akṣayato yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /🔽evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāmasaṃkhyeyānāṃ sattvānāṃ saṃkṣiptāni cittāni saṃkṣiptāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti //
analyzed: sa saṃkṣepam kṣayataḥ kṣayam ca a kṣayataḥ yathābhūtam prajānāti  evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām asaṃkhyeyānām sattvānām saṃkṣiptāni cittāni saṃkṣiptāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: He knows contraction as exhaustion and exhaustion as non-exhaustion as it really is.🔽Thus, Subhuti, the Tathagata, by means of this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is the contracted minds of immeasurable, incalculable beings as contracted minds.

original: punaraparaṃ subhūte tathāgatā imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāmasaṃkhyeyānāṃ sattvānāṃ vikṣiptāni cittāni vikṣiptāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: punar aparam subhūte tathāgatāḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām asaṃkhyeyānām sattvānām vikṣiptāni cittāni vikṣiptāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: Furthermore, Subhuti, the Tathagatas, by means of this perfection of wisdom, know as it really is the distracted minds of immeasurable, incalculable beings as distracted minds.

original: kathaṃ ca subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāmasaṃkhyeyānāṃ sattvānāṃ vikṣiptāni cittāni vikṣiptāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: katham ca subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām asaṃkhyeyānām sattvānām vikṣiptāni cittāni vikṣiptāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam
translated: And how, Subhuti, does the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, know as it really is the distracted minds of immeasurable, incalculable beings as distracted minds?

analyzed: dharmatātaḥ subhūte tāni cittāni vikṣiptāni
translated: Subhuti, those minds are distracted from the nature of dharmas.

original: alakṣaṇāni hi tāni cittāni akṣīṇānyavikṣīṇānyavikṣiptāni tāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /🔽evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgatā imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāmasaṃkhyeyānāṃ sattvānāṃ vikṣiptāni cittāni vikṣiptāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti //
analyzed: alakṣaṇāni hi tāni cittāni akṣīṇāni avikṣīṇāni avikṣiptāni tāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti  evam hi subhūte tathāgatāḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām asaṃkhyeyānām sattvānām vikṣiptāni cittāni vikṣiptāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: He knows as it really is that those minds are undistracted, undestroyed, and unscattered, because those minds are without distinguishing marks.🔽In this way, Subhuti, the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is the distracted minds of immeasurable, incalculable beings as distracted minds.

original: punaraparaṃ subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāmasaṃkhyeyānāṃ sattvānāmaprameyākṣayāṇi cittānyaprameyākṣayāṇi cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: punar aparam subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām asaṃkhyeyānām sattvānām aprameya akṣayāṇi cittāni aprameya akṣayāṇi cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: Furthermore, Subhuti, the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is the immeasurable, inexhaustible minds of immeasurable, incalculable beings as immeasurable, inexhaustible minds.

original: kathaṃ ca subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāmasaṃkhyeyānāṃ sattvānāmaprameyākṣayāṇi cittāni aprameyākṣayāṇi cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ🔽tasya subhūte tathāgatasyādhiṣṭhitaṃ bhavati taccittam /
analyzed: katham ca subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām asaṃkhyeyānām sattvānām aprameya akṣayāṇi cittāni aprameya akṣayāṇi cittāni iti yathābhūtam  tasya subhūte tathāgatasya adhiṣṭhitam bhavati tat cittam
translated: And how, Subhuti, does the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, know as it really is the immeasurable and inexhaustible minds of immeasurable and innumerable beings as immeasurable and inexhaustible?

original: anirodhamanutpādamasthitamanāśrayamasamamaprameyamasaṃkhyeyam /🔽yenaiva yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti ākāśāprameyākṣayatayā cittāprameyākṣayateti /🔽evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāmasaṃkhyeyānāṃ sattvānāmaprameyākṣayāṇi cittānyaprameyākṣayāṇi cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti //
analyzed: anirodham anutpādam asthitam anāśrayam asamam aprameyam asaṃkhyeyam  yena eva yathābhūtam prajānāti ākāśa aprameya akṣaya tayā citta aprameya akṣaya tā iti  evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām asaṃkhyeyānām sattvānām aprameya akṣayāṇi cittāni aprameya akṣayāṇi cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: That mind, Subhuti, is blessed by the Tathagata as unceased, unborn, unstayed, unbased, unequaled, immeasurable, innumerable.🔽By that very one he knows as it really is the immeasurable and inexhaustible mind as immeasurable and inexhaustible, by way of the immeasurable and inexhaustible space.🔽In this way, Subhuti, the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is the immeasurable and inexhaustible minds of immeasurable and innumerable beings as immeasurable and inexhaustible.

original: punaraparaṃ subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāṃ saṃkliṣṭāni cittāni saṃkliṣṭāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti
analyzed: punar aparam subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām saṃkliṣṭāni cittāni saṃkliṣṭāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: Furthermore, Subhuti, the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is the defiled minds of immeasurable beings as defiled minds,

original: kathaṃ ca subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāṃ saṃkliṣṭāni cittāni saṃkliṣṭāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: katham ca subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām saṃkliṣṭāni cittāni saṃkliṣṭāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: And how, Subhuti, does the Tathagata, after resorting to this perfection of wisdom, know the defiled minds of immeasurable beings as defiled minds?

analyzed: a saṃkleśa saṃkliṣṭāni subhūte tāni cittāni a saṃketāni
translated: Subhuti, those minds are undefiled and defiled, unsignaled.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāṃ saṃkliṣṭāni cittāni saṃkliṣṭāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti //
analyzed: evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām saṃkliṣṭāni cittāni saṃkliṣṭāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: Thus, Subhuti, the Tathagata, after resorting to this perfection of wisdom, knows the defiled minds of immeasurable beings as defiled minds.

original: punaraparaṃ subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāmasaṃkliṣṭāni cittānyasaṃkliṣṭāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti
analyzed: punar aparam subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām asaṃkliṣṭāni cittāni asaṃkliṣṭāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: Furthermore, Subhuti, the Tathagata, after resorting to this perfection of wisdom, knows the undefiled minds of immeasurable beings as undefiled minds.

original: kathaṃ ca subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāmasaṃkliṣṭāni cittānyasaṃkliṣṭāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: katham ca subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām asaṃkliṣṭāni cittāni asaṃkliṣṭāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: And how, Subhuti, does the Tathagata, after resorting to this perfection of wisdom, know the undefiled minds of immeasurable beings as undefiled minds?

analyzed: prakṛti prabhāsvarāṇi subhūte tāni cittāni
translated: Subhuti, those minds are naturally radiant.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāmasaṃkliṣṭāni cittānyasaṃkliṣṭāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti //🔽punaraparaṃ subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāṃ līnāni cittāni līnāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām asaṃkliṣṭāni cittāni asaṃkliṣṭāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti  punar aparam subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām līnāni cittāni līnāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: In this way, Subhuti, the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is the unconfused minds of innumerable beings as unconfused minds.🔽Furthermore, Subhuti, the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is the withdrawn minds of innumerable beings as withdrawn minds.

original: kathaṃ ca subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāṃ līnāni cittāni līnāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: katham ca subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām līnāni cittāni līnāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: And how, Subhuti, does the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, know as it really is the withdrawn minds of innumerable beings as withdrawn minds?

analyzed: punar aparam subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām samāhitāni cittāni samāhitāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti

translated: And how, Subhuti, does the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, know as it really is that the minds of innumerable beings are concentrated, that the minds of innumerable beings are concentrated?

analyzed: samasamāni hi subhūte tāni cittāni samavahitāni

analyzed: evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām samāhitāni cittāni samāhitāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: In this way, Subhuti, the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is that the minds of innumerable beings are concentrated, that the minds of innumerable beings are concentrated.

translated: Furthermore, Subhuti, the Tathagata, by means of this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is the minds of innumerable beings that are not liberated as minds that are not liberated.

original: kathaṃ ca subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāmavimuktāni cittānyavimuktāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: katham ca subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām avimuktāni cittāni avimuktāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: And how, Subhuti, does the Tathagata, by means of this perfection of wisdom, know as it really is the minds of innumerable beings that are not liberated as minds that are not liberated?

original: svabhāvavimuktāni subhūte tāni cittāni abhāvasvabhāvāni /🔽evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāmavimuktāni cittānyavimuktāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti //
analyzed: svabhāva vimuktāni subhūte tāni cittāni abhāva svabhāvāni  evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām avimuktāni cittāni avimuktāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: Subhuti, those minds are liberated by their very nature, they are of the nature of non-existence.🔽Thus, Subhuti, the Tathagata, by means of this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is the minds of innumerable beings that are not liberated as minds that are not liberated.

original: punaraparaṃ subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāṃ vimuktāni cittāni vimuktāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: punar aparam subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām vimuktāni cittāni vimuktāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: Furthermore, Subhuti, the Tathagata, by means of this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is the minds of innumerable beings that are liberated as minds that are liberated.

original: kathaṃ ca subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāṃ vimuktāni cittāni vimuktāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: katham ca subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām vimuktāni cittāni vimuktāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: And how, Subhuti, does the Tathagata, after resorting to this perfection of wisdom, know as it really is that the minds of immeasurable beings are liberated, that the minds of immeasurable beings are liberated?

original: cittaḥ hi subhūte tathāgatena na atītamupalabdhaṃ na anāgatam /
analyzed: cittaḥ hi subhūte tathāgatena na atītam upalabdham na anāgatam
translated: The mind, Subhuti, has not been apprehended by the Tathagata as past, nor as future,

analyzed: na pratyutpannam upalabdham
translated: nor as present.

analyzed: asattvāt cittasya
translated: Because the mind does not exist.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāṃ vimuktāni cittāni vimuktāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti //
analyzed: evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām vimuktāni cittāni vimuktāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: Thus, Subhuti, the Tathagata, after resorting to this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is that the minds of immeasurable beings are liberated, that the minds of immeasurable beings are liberated.

original: punaraparaṃ subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāmadṛśyāni cittānyadṛśyāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /

translated: Furthermore, Subhuti, the Tathagata, after resorting to this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is that the minds of immeasurable beings are invisible, that the minds of immeasurable beings are invisible.

original: kathaṃ ca subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāmadṛśyāni cittānyadṛśyāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: katham ca subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām adṛśyāni cittāni adṛśyāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: And how, Subhuti, does the Tathagata, after resorting to this perfection of wisdom, know as it really is that the minds of immeasurable beings are invisible, that the minds of immeasurable beings are invisible?

analyzed: asattvāt subhūte adṛśyam tat cittam
translated: Because, Subhuti, that mind does not exist, it is invisible.

analyzed: a bhūta tvāt avijñeyam
translated: Because it is non-existent, it is unknowable.

analyzed: a pariniṣpattitaḥ grāhyam prajñā cakṣuṣā divyena cakṣuṣā
translated: Because it is unaccomplished, it is ungraspable by the eye of wisdom or the divine eye.

analyzed: kutas punar māṃsa cakṣuṣā
translated: How much less by the fleshly eye.

analyzed: sarveṣām an avabhāsa gata tvāt
translated: Because it is not an object of perception for any of them.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāṃ sattvānāmadṛśyāni cittānyadṛśyāni cittānīti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām sattvānām adṛśyāni cittāni adṛśyāni cittāni iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: In this way, Subhuti, the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, truly knows the invisible minds of immeasurable beings as invisible minds.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte prajñāpāramitā tathāgatānāmarhatāṃ samyaksaṃbuddhānāmasya lokasya saṃdarśayitrī //🔽punaraparaṃ subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāsaṃkhyeyānāṃ parasattvānāṃ parapudgalānāmunmiñjitanimiñjitāni yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: evam hi subhūte prajñāpāramitā tathāgatānām arhatām samyaksaṃbuddhānām asya lokasya saṃdarśayitrī  punar aparam subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇa asaṃkhyeyānām para sattvānām para pudgalānām unmiñjita nimiñjitāni yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: In this way, Subhuti, the perfection of wisdom reveals this world to the Tathagatas, the Arhats, the Fully Enlightened Ones.🔽Furthermore, Subhuti, the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, truly knows the opening and closing of the eyes of immeasurable, incalculable other beings, other persons.

original: kathaṃ ca subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāmasaṃkhyeyāṇāṃ parasattvānāṃ parapudgalānāmunmiñjitanimiñjitāni yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: katham ca subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām asaṃkhyeyāṇām para sattvānām para pudgalānām unmiñjita nimiñjitāni yathābhūtam
translated: And how, Subhuti, does the Tathagata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, truly know the opening and closing of the eyes of immeasurable, incalculable other beings, other persons?

original: sarvāṇi tāni subhūte rūpaniśritāni utpadyamānānyutpadyante iti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /🔽evaṃ vedanā saṃjñā saṃskārāḥ /
analyzed: sarvāṇi tāni subhūte rūpa niśritāni utpadyamānāni utpadyante iti yathābhūtam prajānāti  evam vedanā saṃjñā saṃskārāḥ
translated: Subhūti, he knows as it truly is that all those [arising dharmas] arise based on form.

original: sarvāṇi tāni vijñānaniśritāni utpadyamānānyutpadyante iti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: sarvāṇi tāni vijñāna niśritāni utpadyamānāni utpadyante iti yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: Similarly, he knows as it truly is that all those [arising dharmas] arise based on feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness.

original: tatra subhūte kathaṃ tathāgatena tānyunmiñjitanimiñjitāni rūpaniśritāni vijñātāni bhavanti /🔽evaṃ vedanā saṃjñā saṃskārāḥ /
analyzed: tatra subhūte katham tathāgatena tāni unmiñjita nimiñjitāni rūpa niśritāni vijñātāni bhavanti  evam vedanā saṃjñā saṃskārāḥ
translated: Subhūti, how are those opening and closing [of the eyes] known by the Tathāgata to be based on form?

original: kathaṃ tathāgatena tānyunmiñjitanimiñjitāni vijñānaniśritāni vijñātāni bhavanti /
analyzed: katham tathāgatena tāni unmiñjita nimiñjitāni vijñāna niśritāni vijñātāni bhavanti
translated: Similarly, how are those [opening and closing of the eyes] known by the Tathāgata to be based on feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness?

analyzed: bhavati tathāgataḥ param maraṇāt iti rūpa gatam etat
translated: The Tathāgata exists after death - this is a matter of form.

original: na bhavati tathāgataḥ paraṃ maraṇāditi rūpagatametat /🔽bhavati ca na bhavati ca tathāgataḥ paraṃ maraṇāditi rūpagatametat /
analyzed: na bhavati tathāgataḥ param maraṇāt iti rūpa gatam etat  bhavati ca na bhavati ca tathāgataḥ param maraṇāt iti rūpa gatam etat
translated: The Tathāgata does not exist after death - this is a matter of form.🔽The Tathāgata both exists and does not exist after death - this is a matter of form.

original: naiva bhavati na na bhavati tathāgataḥ paraṃ maraṇāditi rūpagatametat /
analyzed: na eva bhavati na na bhavati tathāgataḥ param maraṇāt iti rūpa gatam etat
translated: The Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist after death - this is a matter of form.

analyzed: evam vedanā saṃjñā saṃskārāḥ
translated: Similarly, [this applies to] feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness.

analyzed: bhavati tathāgataḥ param maraṇāt iti vijñāna gatam etat
translated: The Tathāgata exists after death is a matter of consciousness.

original: na bhavati tathāgataḥ paraṃ maraṇāditi vijñānagatametat /🔽bhavati ca na bhavati ca tathāgataḥ paraṃ maraṇāditi vijñānagatametat /
analyzed: na bhavati tathāgataḥ param maraṇāt iti vijñāna gatam etat  bhavati ca na bhavati ca tathāgataḥ param maraṇāt iti vijñāna gatam etat
translated: The Tathāgata does not exist after death is a matter of consciousness.🔽The Tathāgata both exists and does not exist after death is a matter of consciousness.

original: naiva bhavati na na bhavati tathāgataḥ paraṃ maraṇāditi vijñānagatametat /🔽śāśvata ātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi rūpagatametat /
analyzed: na eva bhavati na na bhavati tathāgataḥ param maraṇāt iti vijñāna gatam etat  śāśvataḥ ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti rūpa gatam etat
translated: The Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist after death is a matter of consciousness.🔽The self and the world are eternal - this alone is true, the rest is delusion - this is a matter of form.

original: aśāśvata ātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi rūpagatametat /🔽śāśvataśca aśāśvata ātmāvalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi rūpagatametat /
analyzed: aśāśvataḥ ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti rūpa gatam etat  śāśvataḥ ca aśāśvataḥ ātma avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti rūpa gatam etat
translated: The self and the world are not eternal - this alone is true, the rest is delusion - this is a matter of form.🔽The self and the world are both eternal and not eternal - this alone is true, the rest is delusion - this is a matter of form.

original: naiva śāśvato nāśāśvata ātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi rūpagatametat /
analyzed: na eva śāśvataḥ na aśāśvataḥ ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti rūpa gatam etat
translated: The self and the world are neither eternal nor not eternal - this alone is true, the rest is delusion - this is a matter of form.

analyzed: evam vedanā saṃjñā saṃskārāḥ
translated: Thus, with regard to feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness:

original: śāśvata ātmāvalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi vijñānagatametat /
analyzed: śāśvataḥ ātma avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti vijñāna gatam etat
translated: The self and the world are eternal - this alone is true, the rest is delusion - this is a matter of consciousness.

original: aśāśvata ātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi vijñānagatametat /🔽śāśvataścāśāśvata ātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi vijñānagatametat /
analyzed: aśāśvataḥ ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti vijñāna gatam etat  śāśvataḥ ca aśāśvataḥ ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti vijñāna gatam etat
translated: The self and the world are impermanent. This alone is true, anything else is delusion. This is a view belonging to the realm of consciousness.🔽The self and the world are both permanent and impermanent. This alone is true, anything else is delusion. This is a view belonging to the realm of consciousness.

original: naiva śāśvato nāśāśvata ātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi vijñānagatametat /🔽antavānātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi rūpagatametat /
analyzed: na eva śāśvataḥ na aśāśvataḥ ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti vijñāna gatam etat  antavān ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti rūpa gatam etat
translated: The self and the world are neither permanent nor impermanent. This alone is true, anything else is delusion. This is a view belonging to the realm of consciousness.🔽The self and the world have an end. This alone is true, anything else is delusion. This is a view belonging to the realm of form.

original: anantavānātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi rūpagatametat /🔽antavāṃśca anantavāṃścātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi rūpagatametat /
analyzed: anantavān ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti rūpa gatam etat  antavān ca anantavān ca ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti rūpa gatam etat
translated: The self and the world are infinite. This alone is true, anything else is delusion. This is a view belonging to the realm of form.🔽The self and the world are both finite and infinite. This alone is true, anything else is delusion. This is a view belonging to the realm of form.

original: naivāntavān nānantavānātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi rūpagatametat /
analyzed: na eva antavān na anantavān ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti rūpa gatam etat
translated: The self and the world are neither finite nor infinite. This alone is true, anything else is delusion. This is a view belonging to the realm of form.

analyzed: evam vedanā saṃjñā saṃskārāḥ
translated: Similarly for feeling, perception, and volitional formations.

original: antavānātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi vijñānagatametat /
analyzed: antavān ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti vijñāna gatam etat
translated: The self and the world have an end. This alone is true, anything else is delusion. This is a view belonging to the realm of consciousness.

original: anantavānātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi vijñānagatametat /🔽antavāṃśca anantavāṃścātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi vijñānagatametat /
analyzed: anantavān ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti vijñāna gatam etat  antavān ca anantavān ca ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti vijñāna gatam etat
translated: The self is infinite, and the soul is visible. This alone is true, the rest is ignorance. This is a view based on consciousness.🔽The self is both finite and infinite, and the soul is visible. This alone is true, the rest is ignorance. This is a view based on consciousness.

original: naivāntavān nānantavānātmā avalokaśca idameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi vijñānagatametat /🔽sa jīvastaccharīramidameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi rūpagatametat /
analyzed: na eva antavān na anantavān ātmā avalokaḥ ca idam eva satyam moham anyat iti vijñāna gatam etat  sa jīvaḥ tat śarīram idam eva satyam moham anyat iti rūpa gatam etat
translated: The self is neither finite nor infinite, and the soul is visible. This alone is true, the rest is ignorance. This is a view based on consciousness.🔽The living being is the same as the body. This alone is true, the rest is ignorance. This is a view based on form.

analyzed: anyaḥ jīvaḥ anyat śarīram idam eva satyam moham anyat iti rūpa gatam etat
translated: The living being is different from the body. This alone is true, the rest is ignorance. This is a view based on form.

original: evaṃ vedanā saṃjñā saṃskārāḥ /🔽sa jīvastaccharīramidameva satyaṃ mohamanyaditi vijñānagatametat /
analyzed: evam vedanā saṃjñā saṃskārāḥ  sa jīvaḥ tat śarīram idam eva satyam moham anyat iti vijñāna gatam etat
translated: Similarly for feeling, perception, and volitional formations.🔽The living being is the same as the body. This alone is true, the rest is ignorance. This is a view based on consciousness.

analyzed: anyaḥ jīvaḥ anyat śarīram idam eva satyam moham anyat iti vijñāna gatam etat
translated: The living being is different from the body. This alone is true, the rest is ignorance. This is a view based on consciousness.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgatenārhatā samyaksaṃbuddhena imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāsaṃkhyeyānāṃ parasattvānāṃ parapudgalānāṃ tānyunmiñjitanimiñjitāni rūpaniśritāni vijñātāni bhavanti /
analyzed: evam hi subhūte tathāgatena arhatā samyaksaṃbuddhena imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇa asaṃkhyeyānām para sattvānām para pudgalānām tāni unmiñjita nimiñjitāni rūpa niśritāni vijñātāni bhavanti
translated: In this way, Subhuti, the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, having relied on this perfection of wisdom, knows those movements of the eyes of immeasurable, incalculable other beings, other persons, based on form.

analyzed: evam vedanā saṃjñā saṃskārāḥ
translated: In the same way, he knows those movements of the eyes based on feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness.🔽In this way, Subhuti, the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, having relied on this perfection of wisdom, knows those movements of the eyes of immeasurable, incalculable other beings, other persons, based on form.

analyzed: tāni unmiñjita nimiñjitāni vijñāna niśritāni vijñātāni bhavanti
translated: In this way, he knows those movements of the eyes based on feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness.

original: punaraparaṃ subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāmamasaṃkhyeyānāṃ parasattvānāṃ parapudgalānāṃ tānyunmiñjitanimiñjitāni yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: punar aparam subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām amasaṃkhyeyānām para sattvānām para pudgalānām tāni unmiñjita nimiñjitāni yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: Moreover, Subhuti, the Tathagata, having relied on this perfection of wisdom, knows those movements of the eyes of immeasurable, incalculable other beings, other persons, as they really are.

analyzed: iha subhūte tathāgataḥ rūpam jānāti
translated: Here, Subhuti, the Tathagata knows form.

original: kathaṃ ca subhūte tathāgato rūpaṃ jānāti /
analyzed: katham ca subhūte tathāgataḥ rūpam jānāti
translated: And how does the Tathagata know form, Subhuti?

analyzed: tathā subhūte tathāgataḥ rūpam jānāti
translated: In this way, Subhuti, the Tathagata knows form.

analyzed: yathā tathatā
translated: As is suchness.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgato rūpaṃ jānāti /
analyzed: evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ rūpam jānāti
translated: In this way, Subhuti, the Tathagata knows form.

analyzed: evam vedanā saṃjñā saṃskārāḥ
translated: In the same way, he knows feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness.

analyzed: iha subhūte tathāgataḥ vijñānam jānāti
translated: Here, Subhuti, the Tathagata knows consciousness.

original: kathaṃ ca subhūte tathāgato vijñānaṃ jānāti /
analyzed: katham ca subhūte tathāgataḥ vijñānam jānāti
translated: And how does the Tathāgata know consciousness?

analyzed: tathā subhūte tathāgataḥ vijñānam jānāti
translated: The Tathāgata knows consciousness, Subhūti,

analyzed: yathā tathatā
translated: just as suchness.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgato vijñānaṃ jānāti /
analyzed: evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ vijñānam jānāti
translated: Thus, Subhūti, the Tathāgata knows consciousness.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgata imāṃ prajñāpāramitāmāgamya aprameyāṇāmasaṃkhyeyānāṃ parasattvānāṃ parapudgalānāṃ tānyunmiñjitanimiñjitāni yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti /
analyzed: evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ imām prajñāpāramitām āgamya aprameyāṇām asaṃkhyeyānām para sattvānām para pudgalānām tāni unmiñjita nimiñjitāni yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: Thus, Subhūti, the Tathāgata, having approached this perfection of wisdom, knows as it really is the stretching out and contracting of those immeasurable, incalculable other sentient beings, other persons.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgatastathāgatatathatayā ca skandhatathatayā ca unmiñjitanimiñjitatathatayā ca tathatāṃ prajñapayati /
analyzed: evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ tathāgata tathatayā ca skandha tathatayā ca unmiñjita nimiñjita tathatayā ca tathatām prajñapayati
translated: Thus, Subhūti, the Tathāgata designates suchness by means of the suchness of the Tathāgata, the suchness of the aggregates, and the suchness of stretching out and contracting.

analyzed: yā eva ca subhūte skandha tathatā
translated: And, Subhūti, the suchness of the aggregates

analyzed: sā eva lokasya api tathatā
translated: is also the suchness of the world.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

original: uktaṃ hyetatsubhūte tathāgatenapañca skandhā loka iti saṃjñātāḥ iti /
analyzed: uktam hi etat subhūte tathāgatena pañca skandhāḥ lokaḥ iti saṃjñātāḥ iti
translated: Because, Subhūti, this has been said by the Tathāgata: 'The five aggregates are known as the world.'

analyzed: tasmāt tarhi subhūte yā skandha tathatā  sā loka tathatā
translated: Therefore, Subhūti, the suchness of the aggregates🔽is the suchness of the world.

analyzed: yā loka tathatā  sā sarva dharma tathatā
translated: The suchness of the world🔽is the suchness of all dharmas.

analyzed: yā sarva dharma tathatā
translated: The suchness of all dharmas

analyzed: sā srotaāpatti phala tathatā
translated: That is the suchness of the fruit of stream-entry.

analyzed: yā srotaāpatti phala tathatā  sā sakṛdāgāmi phala tathatā
translated: The suchness of the fruit of stream-entry,🔽that is the suchness of the fruit of once-returning.

analyzed: yā sakṛdāgāmi phala tathatā  sā anāgāmi phala tathatā
translated: The suchness of the fruit of once-returning,🔽that is the suchness of the fruit of non-returning.

analyzed: yā anāgami phala tathatā  sā arhat tva phala tathatā
translated: The suchness of the fruit of non-returning,🔽that is the suchness of the fruit of arhatship.

analyzed: yā arhat tva phala tathatā  sā pratyekabuddha tva tathatā
translated: The suchness of the fruit of arhatship,🔽that is the suchness of pratyekabuddhahood.

analyzed: yā pratyekabuddha tva tathatā
translated: The suchness of pratyekabuddhahood,

analyzed: sā tathāgata tathatā
translated: that is the suchness of the Tathāgata.

original: iti hi tathāgatatathatā ca skandhatathatā ca sarvadharmatathatā ca sarvāryaśrāvakapratyekabuddhatathatā ca ekaivaiṣā tathatā anekabhāvābhāvāpagatā anekatvādanānātvādakṣayatvādavikāratvādadvayatvādadvaidhīkāratvāt /
analyzed: iti hi tathāgata tathatā ca skandha tathatā ca sarva dharma tathatā ca sarva ārya śrāvaka pratyekabuddha tathatā ca ekā eva eṣā tathatā aneka bhāva abhāva apagatā aneka tvāt anānā tvāt akṣaya tvāt avikāra tvāt advaya tvāt a dvaidhīkāra tvāt
translated: Thus, the suchness of the Tathāgata, the suchness of the aggregates, the suchness of all dharmas, the suchness of all noble disciples and pratyekabuddhas, this one suchness is devoid of multiplicity and non-existence, because of non-multiplicity, because of non-diversity, because of inexhaustibility, because of immutability, because of non-duality, because of the impossibility of dividing it into two.

original: evameṣā subhūte tathatā tathāgatena prajñāpāramitāmāgamya abhisaṃbuddhā /
analyzed: evam eṣā subhūte tathatā tathāgatena prajñāpāramitām āgamya abhisaṃbuddhā
translated: Thus, Subhūti, this suchness has been fully awakened to by the Tathāgata, having relied on the perfection of wisdom.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte prajñāpāramitā tathāgatānāmarhatāṃ samyaksaṃbuddhānāmasya lokasya saṃdarśayitrī /
analyzed: evam hi subhūte prajñāpāramitā tathāgatānām arhatām samyaksaṃbuddhānām asya lokasya saṃdarśayitrī
translated: Thus, Subhūti, the perfection of wisdom is the one that shows this world to the Tathāgatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Awakened Ones.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgato'sya lokasya lokaṃ saṃdarśayati /
analyzed: evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ asya lokasya lokam saṃdarśayati
translated: In this way, Subhuti, the Tathagata shows this world the world.

original: evaṃ cāsya lokasya darśanaṃ bhavatievaṃ hi subhūte prajñāpāramitā tathāgatānāmarhatāṃ samyaksaṃbuddhānāṃ mātā jananī janayitrī /
analyzed: evam ca asya lokasya darśanam bhavati evam hi subhūte prajñāpāramitā tathāgatānām arhatām samyaksaṃbuddhānām mātā jananī janayitrī
translated: And in this way the world is shown: in this way, Subhuti, the perfection of wisdom is the mother of the Tathagatas, the Arhats, the fully Enlightened Ones, she begets them and gives birth to them.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte tathāgatastathatāmabhisaṃbudhya lokasya tathatāṃ jānāti /🔽avitathatāṃ jānāti /
analyzed: evam hi subhūte tathāgataḥ tathatām abhisaṃbudhya lokasya tathatām jānāti  avitatha tām jānāti
translated: In this way, Subhuti, the Tathagata, having fully known the Suchness, knows the Suchness of this world.🔽He knows the Unmistakenness,

analyzed: an anya tathatām jānāti
translated: he knows the Unaltered Suchness.

original: evaṃ ca subhūte tathāgatastathatāmabhisaṃbuddhaḥ saṃstathāgata ityucyate //
analyzed: evam ca subhūte tathāgataḥ tathatām abhisaṃbuddhaḥ san tathāgataḥ iti ucyate
translated: And in this way, Subhuti, the Tathagata, having fully known the Suchness, is called the Tathagata.

analyzed: sthaviraḥ subhūtiḥ āha gambhīrā bhagavan tathatā
translated: The Elder Subhuti said: Deep, O Lord, is the Suchness.

original: ato bhagavaṃstathatāto buddhānāṃ bhagavatāṃ bodhiḥ prabhāvyate prakāśyate /
analyzed: atas bhagavan tathatātaḥ buddhānām bhagavatām bodhiḥ prabhāvyate prakāśyate
translated: Therefore, O Lord, from the Suchness the enlightenment of the Buddhas, the Lords, is manifested and revealed.

original: ko'tra bhagavan anyo'dhimokṣyate'vinivartanīyo bodhisattvo mahāsattvo'rhan vā paripūrṇasaṃkalpo dṛṣṭisaṃpanno vā pudgalaḥ /
analyzed: kaḥ utra bhagavan anyaḥ ūdhi mokṣyate vinivartanīyaḥ bodhisattvaḥ vā paripūrṇa saṃkalpaḥ dṛṣṭi saṃpannaḥ vā pudgalaḥ
translated: Who, O Lord, will believe in this, except an irreversible Bodhisattva, a great being, or an Arhat whose outflows are exhausted, or a person who has attained to the right view?

original: tathā hi bhagavan imāni sthānāni paramagambhīrāṇi tathāgatenābhisaṃbudhya ākhyātāni /
analyzed: tathā hi bhagavan imāni sthānāni parama gambhīrāṇi tathāgatena abhisaṃbudhya ākhyātāni
translated: For thus, Blessed One, these topics are supremely profound, taught by the Tathāgata after attaining perfect enlightenment.

analyzed: evam ukte bhagavān āyuṣmantam subhūtim etat avocat evam etat subhūte evam etat
translated: When this was said, the Blessed One said to the venerable Subhūti, So it is, Subhūti, so it is.

analyzed: parama gambhīrāṇi imāni sthānāni tathāgatena abhisaṃbudhya ākhyātāni
translated: These topics are supremely profound, taught by the Tathāgata after attaining perfect enlightenment.

analyzed: tathā hi subhūte akṣayā eṣā tathatā
translated: For thus, Subhūti, this suchness is inexhaustible,

analyzed: yā tathāgatena abhisaṃbuddhā
translated: which was fully awakened to by the Tathāgata.

analyzed: abhisaṃbudhya akṣayā akṣayā eva ākhyātā
translated: Having fully awakened to it, he has taught it as inexhaustible.

original: atha khalu śakradevendrapramukhāḥ kāmāvacarā rūpāvarāśca devaputrā brahmakāyikānāṃ ca viṃśatidevaputrasahasrāṇi yena bhagavāṃstenopasaṃkramya bhagavataḥ pādau śirasābhivandya ekānte tasthuḥ /
analyzed: atha khalu śakra deva indra pramukhāḥ kāmāvacarāḥ rūpāvarāḥ ca devaputrāḥ brahmakāyikānām ca viṃśati devaputra sahasrāṇi yena bhagavān tena upasaṃkramya bhagavataḥ pādau śirasā abhivandya ekānte tasthuḥ
translated: Then the gods of the desire realm and form realm headed by Śakra, lord of the gods, and twenty thousand gods from the Brahma realm approached the Blessed One, bowed their heads at the feet of the Blessed One, and stood to one side.

original: ekāntasthitāśca te kāmāvacarā rūpāvacarāśca devaputrā bhagavantametadavocangambhīrā bhagavan dharmāḥ prakāśyante /
analyzed: ekānta sthitāḥ ca te kāmāvacarāḥ rūpāvacarāḥ ca deva putrāḥ bhagavantam etat avocan gambhīrāḥ bhagavan dharmāḥ prakāśyante
translated: While standing to one side, those gods of the desire realm and form realm said this to the Blessed One: Blessed One, profound dharmas are being taught.

analyzed: katham bhagavan atra lakṣaṇāni sthāpyante
translated: Blessed One, how are the characteristics established here?

analyzed: bhagavān āha śūnyam iti deva putrāḥ atra lakṣaṇāni sthāpyante
translated: The Blessed One said, Devaputras, the characteristics are established here as empty.

original: ānimittamiti apraṇihitamiti devaputrā atra lakṣaṇāni sthāpyante /
analyzed: ānimittam iti apraṇihitam iti deva putrāḥ atra lakṣaṇāni sthāpyante
translated: Devaputras, the characteristics are established here as signless, as wishless,

original: anabhisaṃskāra iti anutpāda iti anirodha iti asaṃkleśa iti avyavadānamiti abhāva iti nirvāṇamiti dharmadhāturiti tathateti devaputrā atra lakṣaṇāni sthāpyante /
analyzed: an abhisaṃskāraḥ iti an utpādaḥ iti a nirodhaḥ iti a saṃkleśaḥ iti a vyavadānam iti abhāvaḥ iti nirvāṇam iti dharmadhātuḥ iti tathatā iti deva putrāḥ atra lakṣaṇāni sthāpyante
translated: as unconditioned, as non-arising, as non-ceasing, as non-afflicted, as non-purified, as non-existent, as nirvana, as the dharma realm, and as suchness.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: a niśritāni hi deva putrāḥ etāni lakṣaṇāni
translated: Devaputras, these characteristics are not based on anything.

analyzed: ākāśa sadṛśāni hi deva putrāḥ etāni lakṣaṇāni
translated: Devaputras, these characteristics are like space.

analyzed: na etāni lakṣaṇāni tathāgatena arhatā samyaksaṃbuddhena sthāpitāni
translated: These characteristics were not established by the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One.

analyzed: na etāni lakṣaṇāni rūpa saṃkhyātāni
translated: These characteristics are not counted as form.

analyzed: evam na vedanā saṃjñā saṃskāra vijñāna saṃkhyātāni
translated: Similarly, they are not counted as feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness.

analyzed: na etāni lakṣaṇāni rūpa niśritāni
translated: These characteristics are not based on form.

analyzed: na vedanā saṃjñā saṃskāra vijñāna niśritāni
translated: They are not based on feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness.

original: naitāni lakṣaṇāni devairvā nāgairvā manuṣyairvā amanuṣyairvā sthāpitāni /
analyzed: na etāni lakṣaṇāni devaiḥ vā nāgaiḥ vā manuṣyaiḥ vā amanuṣyaiḥ vā sthāpitāni
translated: These characteristics were not established by gods, nagas, humans, or non-humans.

original: naitāni lakṣaṇāni sadevamānuṣāsureṇa lokena śakyāni cālayitum /
analyzed: na etāni lakṣaṇāni sa deva mānuṣa asureṇa lokena śakyāni cālayitum
translated: These characteristics cannot be shaken by the world with its gods, humans, and asuras.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: sa deva mānuṣa asuraḥ api hi lokaḥ etad lakṣaṇaḥ eva
translated: The world with its gods, humans, and asuras is characterized by just that.

analyzed: na api etāni lakṣaṇāni kena api hastena sthāpitāni
translated: And these characteristics are not established by anyone's hand.

original: yo devaputrā evaṃ vadetidamākāśaṃ kenāpi sthāpitamiti /
analyzed: yaḥ deva putrāḥ evam vada iti idam ākāśam kena api sthāpitam iti
translated: If, sons of gods, someone were to say, 'This space is established by someone,'

original: api nu sa devaputrāḥ samyagvadan vadet /
analyzed: api nu sa deva putrāḥ samyak vadan vadet
translated: would those sons of gods speak correctly?

original: evamukte kāmāvacarā rūpāvarāśca devaputrā bhagavantametadavocanna bhagavan ākāśaṃ kenacitsthāpitam /
analyzed: evam ukte kāmāvacarāḥ rūpāvarāḥ ca deva putrāḥ bhagavantam etat avocat na bhagavan ākāśam kenacid sthāpitam
translated: When this was said, the gods of the desire realm and the gods of the form realm said to the Blessed One, Blessed One, space is not established by anyone.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: a saṃskṛta tvāt bhagavan ākāśasya na ākāśam kenacid sthāpitam
translated: Because space is unconditioned, Blessed One, space is not established by anyone.

original: atha khalu bhagavāṃstān kāmāvacarān rūpāvarāṃśca devaputrānāmantrayate smaevametaddevaputrāḥ /
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavān tān kāmāvacarān rūpāvarān ca deva putrān āmantrayate sma evam etat deva putrāḥ
translated: Then the Blessed One addressed those gods of the desire realm and the gods of the form realm, saying, So it is, gods!

analyzed: utpādāt vā tathāgatānām anutpādāt vā tathā eva etāni lakṣaṇāni sthitāni
translated: Whether the Tathāgatas arise or do not arise, these characteristics remain just as they are.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: yathā etāni hi sthitāni
translated: Because they remain just as they are.

analyzed: tathābhūtāni tathāgatena abhisaṃbudhya ākhyātāni
translated: The Tathāgata, having fully awakened to them as they really are, has proclaimed them.

analyzed: tasmāt deva putrāḥ tathāgataḥ tathāgataḥ iti ucyate
translated: Therefore, sons of gods, the Tathāgata is called the Tathāgata.”

original: atha khalvāyuṣmān subhūtirbhagavantametadavocatgambhīrāṇi bhagavan imāni lakṣaṇāni tathāgatenābhisaṃbuddhāni /
analyzed: atha khalu āyuṣmān subhūtiḥ bhagavantam etat avocat gambhīrāṇi bhagavan imāni lakṣaṇāni tathāgatena abhisaṃbuddhāni
translated: Then the venerable Subhūti said this to the Blessed One: “Blessed One, these profound characteristics have been fully awakened to by the Tathāgata.

analyzed: tathāgatānām ca asaṅga jñānam yat uta prajñāpāramitā
translated: And the unobstructed knowledge of the Tathāgatas is this: the perfection of wisdom.

analyzed: asaṅga jñānāya prajñāpāramitā tathāgatānām gocaraḥ
translated: The perfection of wisdom is the domain of the Tathāgatas for unobstructed knowledge.

analyzed: evam ukte bhagavān āyuṣmantam subhūtim etat avocat evam etat subhūte evam etat
translated: When this was said, the Blessed One said to the venerable Subhūti: “It is so, Subhūti, it is so.

original: evaṃ hi subhūte prajñāpāramitā tathāgatānāmarhatāṃ samyaksaṃbuddhānāmasya lokasya saṃdarśayitrī /
analyzed: evam hi subhūte prajñāpāramitā tathāgatānām arhatām samyaksaṃbuddhānām asya lokasya saṃdarśayitrī
translated: Subhūti, in this way the perfection of wisdom reveals this world to the Tathāgatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Awakened Ones.

original: yathā subhūte tathāgatā arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhā imāṃ dharmaṃ prajñāpāramitāmupaniśritya viharanti /
analyzed: yathā subhūte tathāgatāḥ arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ imām dharmam prajñāpāramitām upaniśritya viharanti
translated: Subhūti, just as the Tathāgatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Awakened Ones, relying on this perfection of wisdom, the Dharma, dwell,

analyzed: tathā eva ete dharmāḥ sadā sthitāḥ
translated: in the same way these dharmas have always been established.

analyzed: asthānataḥ tathāgataiḥ abhisaṃbuddhāḥ
translated: They have been fully awakened to by the Tathāgatas as non-abiding.

analyzed: atas te dharmam eva upaniśritya viharanti
translated: Therefore, they dwell relying on the Dharma itself.

analyzed: dharmam satkurvanti gurukurvanti mānayanti pūjayanti arcayanti apacāyanti
translated: They honor, respect, revere, and worship the Dharma.

original: prajñāpāramitaivaiṣā subhūte dharmāṇāṃ dharmateti tathāgatā arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ prajñāpāramitāṃ satkurvanti gurukurvanti mānayanti pūjayantyarcayantyapacāyanti
analyzed: prajñāpāramitā eva eṣā subhūte dharmāṇām dharma tā iti tathāgatāḥ arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ prajñāpāramitām satkurvanti gurukurvanti mānayanti pūjayanti arcayanti apacāyanti
translated: Subhūti, the Tathāgatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Awakened Ones honor, respect, revere, worship, and praise the perfection of wisdom, because it is the suchness of dharmas.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

original: ato hi subhūte prajñāpāramitātastathāgatānāmarhatāṃ samyaksaṃbuddhānāṃ sarvajñatāyāḥ prabhāvanā bhavati /
analyzed: atas hi subhūte prajñāpāramitātaḥ tathāgatānām arhatām samyaksaṃbuddhānām sarvajña tāyāḥ prabhāvanā bhavati
translated: Subhūti, from this perfection of wisdom comes the manifestation of the omniscience of the Tathāgatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Awakened Ones.

original: kṛtajñāḥ kṛtavedinaśca tathāgatā arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ /🔽yatkhalu subhūte samyagvadanto vadeyuḥkṛtajñaḥ kṛtavedīti /
analyzed: kṛtajñāḥ kṛta vedinaḥ ca tathāgatāḥ arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ  yat khalu subhūte samyak vadantaḥ vadeyuḥ kṛtajñaḥ kṛta vedī iti
translated: The Tathāgatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Awakened Ones are grateful and appreciative.🔽Subhūti, those who speak correctly would say that the Tathāgata is grateful and appreciative.

original: tattathāgataṃ hi te samyagvadanto vadantikṛtajñaḥ kṛtavedīti /
analyzed: tat tathāgatam hi te samyak vadantaḥ vadanti kṛtajñaḥ kṛtavedī iti
translated: Those who speak correctly say that the Tathāgata is grateful and appreciative.

original: yatkhalu subhūte tathāgato'rhan samyaksaṃbuddho yena yena yānenāgataḥ /

analyzed: tayā eva kṛtajña tayā kṛta veditayā

analyzed: punar aparam subhūte tathāgatena sarva dharmāḥ akṛtāḥ akṛtāḥ iti abhisaṃbuddhāḥ  avikṛtāḥ avikṛtāḥ iti ami saṃbuddhāḥ
translated: Moreover, Subhūti, all dharmas have been fully awakened to by the Tathāgata as unmade, unmade.🔽They have been fully awakened to as unaltered, unaltered.

original: prajñāpāramitāṃ hyāgamya subhūte tathāgatasyārhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya evaṃ sarvadharmeṣu jñānaṃ pravṛttam /
analyzed: prajñāpāramitām hi āgamya subhūte tathāgatasya arhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya evam sarva dharmeṣu jñānam pravṛttam

translated: By this method also, Subhūti, the perfection of wisdom reveals this world to the Tathāgatas, the Arhats, the Perfectly Awakened Ones.

analyzed: sarva dharmāḥ a jānakāḥ a paśyakāḥ

original: evamapi subhūte prajñāpāramitā tathāgatānāmarhatāṃ samyaksaṃbuddhānāmasya lokasya saṃdarśayitrī rūpasyādṛṣṭatvāt /

analyzed: evam vedanāyāḥ saṃjñāyāḥ saṃskārāṇām vijñānasya a dṛṣṭa tvāt saṃdarśayitrī

analyzed: bhagavān āha yadi subhūte na rūpa ārambaṇam vijñānam utpadyate

analyzed: yadi subhūte na vijñāna ārambaṇam vijñānam utpadyate

analyzed: evam vijñānasya a dṛṣṭa tā bhavati

analyzed: yā ca subhūte rūpasya a dṛṣṭa tā

analyzed: yā ca vedanāyāḥ saṃjñāyāḥ saṃskārāṇām

analyzed: yā ca subhūte vijñānasya a dṛṣṭa tā

analyzed: mahā kṛtyena iyam subhūte prajñāpāramitā pratyupasthitā

analyzed: acintya kṛtyena atulya kṛtyena aprameya kṛtyena asaṃkhyeya kṛtyena asamasama kṛtyena iyam subhūte prajñāpāramitā pratyupasthitā

analyzed: kena kāraṇena subhūte rūpasya pramāṇam na vidyate

analyzed: kena kāreṇena subhūte sarva dharmāṇām api pramāṇam na vidyate

analyzed: a pramāṇa tvāt subhūte sarva dharmāṇām

analyzed: rūpam api subhūte asaṃkhyeyam
